facts.text: On September 22, 1947, Rangachari executed three deeds of settlement Exts. A, A-1, A-2 in favour of wife, married adult daughter, minor daughter.

issues.text: Whether the inclusion in the assessee’s total income of the profits settled by him on his wife and two daughters is justified in law?

anchor.surface_text: Whether the inclusion in the assessees total income of the profits settled by him on his wife and two daughters is justified in law ? The High Court answered the question in the affirmative.

issues.text: Whether these amounts could not be included in the assessee’s total income, being excluded by reason of the third proviso to s. 16(1)(c) of the Income-tax Act?

anchor.surface_text: The assessee claimed that these amounts could not be included in his total income for purposes of assessment, being excluded by reason of the third proviso to s. 16 1  c  of the Income-tax Act. He also contended that the amount payable to his wife and two daughters never became his income, being diverted by an overriding title,

issues.text: Whether the amount payable to the wife and two daughters never became the assessee’s income, being diverted by an overriding title and governed by the rule in Bijoy Singh Dudhuria v. Commissioner of Income-tax?

anchor.surface_text: being diverted by an overriding title, and that the case was governed by the rule laid down by the Privy Council in Bijoy Singh Dudhuria v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bengal  1 . The assessees contentions were not accepted by the Income-tax Officer,

issues.text: Whether the transfer to the minor daughter fell within s. 16(3), as there was no adequate consideration for the transfer?

anchor.surface_text: He also held that the transfer to the minor daughter fell within s. 16 3 , as there was no adequate consideration for the transfer. With regard to the wife and married daughter, he held that s. 16 1  c  was not applicable,

issues.text: Whether s. 16(1)(c) was applicable, or whether what had been transferred was income first accruing to the assessee?

anchor.surface_text: With regard to the wife and married daughter, he held that s. 16 1  c  was no applicable, because what had been transferred was income first accruing to the assessee, while s. 16 1  c  contemplated income which accrued to a person,

issues.text: Whether what had been assigned was an actionable claim, namely the right to profits, such that the profits were diverted before accruing to the assessee?

holdings.text: These three cases, in our opinion, afford a complete answer to the contentions of the appellants.

anchor.surface_text: These three cases, in our opinion, afford a complete answer to the contentions of the appellants. An examination of the deeds of settlement shows that the disponer had stated that from the profits payable to h

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct bearing from recent Supreme Court decisions in Provat Kumar Mitter, Tulsidas Kilachand, and Sitaldas Tirathdas applied to identical contentions regarding s.16(1)(c), overriding title, and diversion.

holdings.text: The tenor of the documents shows that the profits were first to accrue to him and were then applied for payments to the disponees.

anchor.surface_text: The tenor of the documents shows that the profits were first to accrue to him and were then applied for payments to the disponees.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Examination of deeds indicates profits payable to settlor first, with directions for portions to be paid to wife and daughters after accrual.

holdings.text: An examination of the deeds of settlement shows that the disponer had stated that from the profits payable to him certain amounts in specified shares were to be paid to his wife and two daughters. No doubt, the assessee in those deeds created a right in favour of the disponees to get the amounts direct from the firm, of which he was a partner.

anchor.surface_text: An examination of the deeds of settlement shows that the disponer had stated that from the profits payable to him certain amounts in specified shares were to be paid to his wife and two daughters. No doubt, the assessee in those deeds created a right in favour of the disponees to get the amounts direct from the firm, of which he was a partner.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual analysis of settlement deeds confirms accrual to assessee prior to application for disponees despite direct payment right.

holdings.text: the rule laid down by the Privy Council in Bijoy Singh Dudhurias case was considered along with the case of the Privy Council in P. C. Mullick v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bengal 5 , and it was pointed out that the rule in Bijoy Singh Dudhurias case 2 applied only to those cases where it could be said that by an overriding title the income was diverted in such a way as never to become the income of the assessee.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishing application from Sitaldas Tirathdas: overriding title doctrine limited to diversion before accrual to assessee.

holdings.text: This, in our opinion, is neither in accordance with the law of partnership nor with the facts as we have found on the record.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Appellants' contention of assignment as actionable claim rejected based on partnership law and record facts.

holdings.text: Under the law of partnership, it is the partner and the partner alone who is entitled to the profits. Astranger, even if he were an assignee, has number and cannot have a direct claim to the profits.

anchor.surface_text: Under the law of partnership, it is the partner and the partner alone who is entitled to the profits. Astranger, even if he were an assignee, has number and cannot have a direct claim to the profits.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct application of partnership law: exclusive entitlement to profits vests in partner, barring direct claims by assignees or strangers.

anchor.surface_text: These three cases, in our opinion, afford a complete answer to the contentions of the appellants. An examination of the deeds of settlement shows that the disponer had stated that from the profits payable to him certain amounts in specified shares were to be paid to his wife and two daughters. No doubt, the assessee in those deeds created a right in favour of the disponees to get the amounts direct from the firm, of which he was a partner.

outcome.relief_summary: Appellants' contentions rejected; three recent Supreme Court cases provide complete answer; profits first accrue to assessee then applied to disponees; no diversion by overriding title; stranger cannot have direct claim to partnership profits
